articles.article: [ ![Equations on a blackboard](https://ichef-1.bbci.co.uk/news/320/cpsprodpb/2B21/production/_100314011_gettyimages-188093718.jpg)Image copyrightGetty ImagesImage caption The Scottish government will make 100 bursaries available for people to retrain as teachers  People considering changing career to teach science, technology, engineering or maths are be offered the chance of a \xa320,000 bursary. The Scottish government said it would fund 100 such bursaries for those taking up training places from August. The grants are part of measures to recruit more teachers in so-called STEM subjects in Scottish schools. Up to 20 teacher training places are also being set aside for those who have lost jobs in the oil and gas sector.  Wider range The 20 places will be available on the University of Aberdeen's post graduate diploma course to local applicants as well as those from Argyll and Bute, Comhairle nan Eilean Siar, Highland, Moray, Orkney and Shetland.    Education Secretary John Swinney said: "We know there are people with the talent and experience needed to inspire the next generation, and we want to make a career in teaching more accessible to a wider range of people. "These bursaries will make it easier for those considering a career change into teaching to take that step, bridging the gap in employment and making a move into teaching a real possibility for many more people." [Applications for the \xa320,000 bursary](https://beta.gov.scot/publications /stem-teacher-education-bursary-eligibility/) will open on 3 April.  ]
articles.title: £20k bursary offer for STEM teachers

articles.article: [   **LONDON** \-- Some of the BBC's highest-paid male broadcasters have agreed to take a pay cut after revelations of a [gender divide in salaries](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/equal-pay-day-5-key-points-about-the- gender-wage-gap/). The [BBC said Friday](http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-42827333) that six of its TV and radio presenters had agreed to reduced salaries, and that "there are further conversations that the BBC will have with others in due course." The network did not say whether it had already increased any female staffers' pay in an effort to redress the imbalance.  * [Why gender pay bias lawsuit vs. Google is a "bid deal"](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/google-lawsuit-gender-pay-gap-nicholas-thompson/)  "We are very grateful to Huw Edwards, Nicky Campbell, John Humphrys, Jon Sopel, Nick Robinson and Jeremy Vine, who have agreed that their pay will now be reduced," the BBC said in a written statement. "These are great journalists and presenters, who have a real connection with the audience. We are proud to have them working at the BBC. Vine, Humphrys and TV news anchorman Huw Edwards were among those who appeared on a list released last year that revealed that two-thirds of the BBC's highest earners were men. Many BBC men were also found to be receiving far higher salaries than women in comparable jobs The BBC's China editor, Carrie Gracie, quit her post earlier this month to protest what she called a failure to address the pay gap. Gracie did not appear on the list of broadcasters earning at least 150,000 pounds ($214,000) a year. ![carrie-gracie-bbc.jpg ](https://cbsnews1.cbsistatic.com/hub/i/r/2018/01/26/6d8ead06-118a-495d-956f- b60936af9cb8/resize/620x/5a7ed161c20fafd34cbc050cd89a9715/carrie-gracie- bbc.jpg) Former BBC News China editor Carrie Gracie.  REUTERS Humphrys, who presents a daily show on Radio 4 and the popular TV quiz show Mastermind, said it was his decision to take the pay cut. "It's the third (cut) and they have been volunteered in each case," he said, noting that things had changed significantly since the days when on-air personalities such as himself had "money pretty much thrust upon us." He said it was clear that in today's economy, "there is a shortage of cash" at the publically funded broadcaster, "and it seems to me, and I thought this before the salary disclosures last year, but the salary disclosures reinforced the idea that some of us were earning much more than others."  ]
articles.title: 6 male BBC presenters take pay cuts over gender divide - CBS News

articles.article: [ If the New York City school system, with its 1.1 million students, were its own metropolis, it would be the 10th largest in the country, bigger than Austin, Indianapolis or San Francisco. And starting next month, there will be a new mayor in town. , [Richard A. Carranza](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/05/nyregion/nyc-schools- chancellor-carranza.html) will become chancellor of the system, with its 75,000 teachers and 1,800 schools, on [April 2](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/09/nyregion/carranza-schools-chancellor- start- april-2.html?rref=collection%2Fbyline%2Felizabeth-a.-harris&action=click&contentCollection=undefined&region=stream&module=stream_unit&version=latest&contentPlacement=2&pgtype=collection), taking on a job that is organizationally complex, intensely political 4 in a word, daunting. , But Mr. Carranza comes to the position with only modest big-district experience on his r\xe9sum\xe9, making it difficult to judge the skills and accomplishments he will bring to the job. He spent seven years in San Francisco, first as a deputy superintendent and then leading the district, but there are just 14 public high schools in San Francisco. In New York, there are more than 400. Then he ran the schools in Houston, which is a larger system, but Mr. Carranza 9s time there was so short that graduation rates from his first year in office have yet to be released. ,  cYou come in with a learning curve and you start to implement change, and then you 9re gone, Rhonda Skillern-Jones, the president of the Houston school board, said of Mr. Carranza 9s legacy. cThere wasn 9t time to make a major overhaul or make a mark even, but there also wasn 9t time to mess anything up. , Before Mayor Bill de Blasio made his choice, he said he would pick someone who would hew closely to the agenda set during his first term by Chancellor Carmen Fari\xf1a. Mr. de Blasio 9s initial selection of Alberto M. Carvalho, superintendent of the Miami-Dade County schools, took some by surprise. Mr. Carvalho had focused on increasing school choice through magnet programs and some charter schools 4 not Mr. de Blasio 9s priority. But he was also a career educator who had demonstrated strong results in increasing graduation rates and was hailed as a shrewd choice. , But after Mr. Carvalho 9s very public about-face in [turning the job down](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/01/nyregion/carvalho-new-york-schools- chancellor.html), the mayor seems to have reverted to a more familiar character. , In San Francisco, Mr. Carranza championed an effort to change discipline practices, a path Ms. Fari\xf1a and Mr. de Blasio have taken as well, and suspensions were reduced by half during his four years as superintendent. In Houston, he started a program called Achieve 180, aimed at improving low- performing schools, which is similar in its approach to Mr. de Blasio 9s [Renewal Schools](https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/04/nyregion/de-blasio- unveils-new-plans-for-troubled-schools-in-new-york.html) program. The Renewal program has [shown mixed results](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/18/nyregion /new-york-city-will-close-or-merge-19-schools-most-from-renewal-program.html) so far, while for [Achieve 180](https://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/houston- texas/houston/article/District-trumpets-launch-of-180-plan-11944994.php), which is still in its first year, it is too soon to tell. , Asked what had attracted the mayor to Mr. Carranza, Dean Fuleihan, first deputy mayor in New York, who was deeply involved in the chancellor search, referred to the focus of his career. cFrom the moment he walks in a classroom, he 9s in an urban setting with largely minority kids, Mr. Fuleihan said. Mr. Carranza 9s commitment to education, he continued, was capparent through each step of his professional career. , At the March 5 news conference announcing his hiring, Mr. Carranza said there was cno daylight between himself and mayor on their beliefs, and for a mayor who hopes to see schools as a key part of his legacy, that was surely appealing. But Mr. de Blasio, a Democrat, also seemed compelled by Mr. Carranza 9s life story. , The grandson of immigrants from Mexico, Mr. Carranza, 51, grew up in Tucson; his mother was a hairdresser, his father a sheet-metal worker. The family spoke Spanish at home, and he learned English in public school. Mr. Carranza, an accomplished mariachi musician, worked his way through college at the University of Arizona, cgigging, he said. He earned a masters in education from Northern Arizona University and has done doctoral coursework at Northern Arizona and Nova Southeastern Universities. , Mr. Carranza has a twin brother, Reuben, who has found success in a very different field: He is a partner at Luxury Brand Partners, a company that makes beauty products carried at high-end department stores like Barneys. , Like Ms.[ Fari\xf1a](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/20/nyregion/carmen- farina-nyc-schools-retire.html), the departing chancellor, Mr. Carranza is a lifelong educator. He has worked in school systems for 27 years, starting as a bilingual social studies and mariachi music teacher at Pueblo Magnet High School in Tucson, where he went on to become principal. Next, his career took him to Las Vegas, where he oversaw 66 schools and 66,000 students as a region superintendent. Then, on to San Francisco, where he was appointed deputy superintendent for instruction, innovation and social justice in 2009. , In 2012, he became San Francisco 9s superintendent. Norman Yee, a member of the board of supervisors in San Francisco and a former president of the city 9s Board of Education, described Mr. Carranza as well liked and effective. ,  cHe didn 9t come in saying, 8I know how to do it the right way and everything else is wrong, 9 Mr. Yee said. cHe had a good sense of what was working and what was not working 4 and getting rid of what was not working. , While Mr. de Blasio 9s relationships with charter schools in New York have often been adversarial, Dave Levin, co-founder of the national charter network KIPP, said that Mr. Carranza was supportive when KIPP wanted to start a high school in San Francisco. cHe was really helpful to us in getting it open, in getting public facilities, being supportive of it even through opposition, Mr. Levin said. , During Mr. Carranza 9s time as deputy superintendent and superintendent, San Francisco saw some measurable success. Graduation rates rose by seven percentage points, and the gap narrowed between the graduation rates of black and Hispanic students and the rates of their white and Asian peers. But he failed to fix a persistent and glaring failure in the district: African- Americans in the city have long scored among the lowest in California on standardized tests. , In 2016, the year that Mr. Carranza left San Francisco, 19 percent of African- American students were at grade level in English and 13 percent in math, according to a [report](https://reports.innovateschools.org/san-francisco- schools-report-2017-home/2017-sf-schools-paradox-great-jobs-out-of-reach/) by Innovate Public Schools, a nonprofit in the Bay Area. , Also during his time in San Francisco, an employee who had been passed over for a leadership position [sued the district](http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/de-blasio-rejects-bias- allegations-new-schools-chancellor-article-1.3866010), saying that Mr. Carranza created a hostile work environment for women, and that he retaliated against her after she saw him flirt with a woman who was not his wife. The suit was settled. , Olivia Lapeyrolerie, the spokeswoman for the de Blasio administration, said City Hall was aware of the suit before hiring Mr. Carranza. cWe 9re confident that the allegation is completely false, she said. cMr. Carranza was never named in the suit nor was he involved in the settlement. , San Francisco has a big name, but with 56,000 students it is tiny compared to New York. New York City 9s District 2, which includes several Manhattan neighborhoods, alone had 64,000 students last school year. There are 32 such districts in the city. ,  cI went to look at the number and said, 8Oh my goodness, 9 said Aaron Pallas, chairman of the Department of Education Policy at Columbia University 9s Teachers College. cGoing to a system that 9s 20 times larger, in many industries you don 9t think of someone moving into a C.E.O. role that is that large of a jump. , The districts Mr. Carranza led have not attracted the national buzz of places like Washington, D.C., or even smaller school systems like Newark 9s, but he has been courted by big cities before. In 2015, he was in the running to lead the Los Angeles Unified School District. An [article](http://www.latimes.com/local/education/la-me-supt- names-20151211-story.html) in The Los Angeles Times said his focuses in San Francisco on reducing suspensions and expanding access to technology were priorities in Los Angeles, as well. But Mr. Carranza removed himself from the competition, [saying](http://www.latimes.com/local/education/administration /la-me-ln-carranza-withdraws-for-la-supt-20160104-story.html) he wanted to stay on in San Francisco. , Then in 2016, he moved on to Houston. Greg Meyers, a former member of the Houston school board who was involved in hiring Mr. Carranza, said that chis drive toward equity, which the board took to be heartfelt, cwas something that really stood out. , In Houston, Mr. Carranza took over a district four times as large as San Francisco 9s, one that has presented him with a long list of challenges. It faces a $115 million budget shortfall and a potential takeover by the state 9s education agency because it failed to improve chronically low- performing schools. Hurricane Harvey wreaked havoc on school buildings and the city 9s neighborhoods, diminished enrollment and threatened property values, which could mean less money for the district. , Mr. Carranza also reported to a nine-member school board where each member is elected by a separate district, which meant their interests could often be at odds. ,  cI think he really, really struggled to define where it was he wanted to take Houston, said Anna Eastman, a former president of the Houston school board who was on the board during Mr. Carranza 9s first year. cI think it 9s hard for anyone to serve in that role with a board that is not really united around a common vision. , The central goals Mr. Carranza articulated in Houston revolved around giving poor students a better shot. One of his major, and most controversial, plans involved making changes to the city 9s magnet-school programs by giving some preference to children from low-income families and eliminating many of the test-score and academic requirements. Houston 9s high-performing magnet schools are dominated by white middle-class families, and factions of the board are fierce defenders of the current rules. , Another significant proposal was a change to the way schools were funded, which would take some discretion away from principals but provide a minimum level of staffing at every school. Neither the funding nor the magnet changes have yet been approved. Mr. Carranza 9s initial magnet proposal, which called for cutting funding to many of the programs, angered parents and [was withdrawn](https://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/education/article/HISD- leaders-back-off-plan-for-deep-cuts-to-11171470.php) **.** , Mr. Fuleihan, Mr. de Blasio 9s deputy mayor, said that while 18 months 4 Mr. Carranza 9s time in Houston 4 was a short tenure, the mayor found the vision Mr. Carranza outlined there to be appealing. Mr. Fuleihan also cited Mr. Carranza 9s response to Hurricane Harvey, after which he quickly reopened [schools](https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/schools-reopen-in- houston-buoying-hope-for-recovery/2017/09/11/fd25bc48-971b-11e7-87fc- c3f7ee4035c9_story.html?utm_term=.8f5854d12e04), as evidence of his management skills, especially in light of bungled responses after other storms, like Hurricane Katrina in New Orleans in 2005. ,  cHow you respond to those things, and how calmly you do it, and how you put things together, Mr. Fuleihan said of what New York officials saw in Mr. Carranza 9s crisis response. cI think that 9s very telling about how you can handle a school system like New York City. , Mr. Fuleihan also pointed out that for any new chancellor, New York would be a big jump. The second-largest district in the country, Los Angeles, serves 640,000 students, about 460,000 fewer than New York. , Nonetheless, others found Mr. Carranza 9s record of accomplishment lacking. Priscilla Wohlstetter, a distinguished research professor at Columbia University 9s Teachers College who studies urban education, said he had neither robust experience in a large district nor an established record of leadership in another big organization, as, for example, some superintendents with [military backgrounds](https://www.districtadministration.com/article /army-strong-superintendent-savvy) have shown. ,  cThe pipeline for superintendents is very thin, Ms. Wohlstetter said. cWe are the largest district in the country, and this is the caliber of person we end up appointing? , Bill Miller, an Austin lobbyist who has represented the Houston school district, said that Mr. Carranza was an can A-plus human being, an A-plus educator, but that he seemed to struggle with the internal politics of his job. cThat 9s not his natural bent, Mr. Miller said. , In New York, he will have just one boss, Mr. de Blasio, which should simplify matters somewhat. But with the city 9s cacophonous media landscape, the external forces Mr. Carranza faces are about to get a turbo charge. ,  cJust as New York City is on steroids in regards to the number of students, said Mr. Pallas of Columbia, cit 9s probably on steroids with regards to the politics, as well. ]
articles.title: For New Schools Chancellor, New York City Is a Big Leap

articles.article: [  [Oracle Corp.](/quote/ORCL:US "Financial Highlights") has never been shy about speaking up in Washington. Last year, that meant lobbying the government on employment regulations while being sued for alleged discrimination. The world 9s second-largest software company spent an estimated $9 million on lobbying, which included pressing Congress and the Department of Labor on issues relating to employment regulations while the department [sued](https://www.dol.gov/newsroom/releases/ofccp/ofccp20170118-0 "Click to view webpage.") Oracle for allegedly paying white men more than other workers with the same titles. The company also pressed lawmakers on the department 9s budget while the suit progressed, according to lobbying data compiled by Bloomberg. The pay discrimination case, which also alleges that Oracle favored Asian applicants for technical roles, is scheduled for a June hearing. The allegations placed Oracle at the nexus of years-long debates regarding the wage gap between men and women and the push for greater ethnic diversity throughout the tech industry.     The Labor Department 9s lawsuit, cfiled three days before the end of the last administration, is entirely without merit and was filed without a single complainant, said Ken Glueck, a senior vice president at Oracle. cThere is a very broad, ongoing effort from nearly the entire business community to communicate to Congress how (the department) is incorrectly and inappropriately abusing its authority. The Labor Department is seeking to [recover](https://www.dol.gov/newsroom/releases/ofccp/ofccp20170118-0 "Department of Labor/Oracle") lost benefits to the affected employees in the suit, including compensation, promotions and stock. Larry Ellison 9s company has spent more than $95 million on lobbying since 2000, making it the third-biggest tech lobbyist in that time. The company filed reports with Congress showing that effort cost more than $12 million in 2017, but the amount will be reduced when Oracle revises its filings, according to Glueck. [Read more about tech industry power in The Influence Game series](https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-amazon-lobbying/ "Click for full story") For years, Oracle, which offers corporate-computing services, has pushed the government to improve its information technology, advocated for lower taxation, and urged an overhaul of the U.S. immigration system while it pressed for federal contracts.     Oracle's Policy Reach  Corporate tech giant has lobbied many government agencies for years    Source: lobbying disclosures  ![](https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iB5.rJiB89Mk/v1/-1x-1.png)     Most of Oracle 9s lobbying last year centered on taxes and immigration, given the firm 9s $58.5 billion in cash held overseas as of Nov. 30 and its international talent pipeline. But the money allocated to employment regulations pointed to a fresh priority for the company during President Donald Trump 9s first year in office, when he and the Republican-led Congress promised business-friendly policies. Trump proposed a cut in the labor department 9s budget last year, including a reduction in enforcement. Oracle shares rose less than 1 percent to $49.77 at 10:55 a.m. in New York.  _ 4 With assistance by Alex Webb, and Bill Allison_  ]
articles.title: Oracle Lobbied Labor Amid Employment Case: The Influence Game

articles.article: [  [American Express Co.](/quote/AXP:US "Bloomberg Intelligence Company Primer") will disclose data on its gender pay gap by the end of the year, according to a shareholder activist that 9s been pushing Wall Street to release the information. The credit-card company pledged to report to shareholders by the end of 2018 any findings on pay disparities, Arjuna Capital said Wednesday in a statement. New York-based AmEx said in a memo to employees that it regularly reviews pay policies to make sure they support pay equality and transparency.  cBased on the most recent comprehensive pay analysis we conducted with a third-party consulting firm, we are confident that our colleagues are compensated equitably, regardless of gender, the company said in the memo. cThe review found no evidence of bias in our compensation processes and indicated we were effectively at parity.     AmEx 9s decision, which came after pressure from Arjuna, follows similar moves by Mastercard Inc. and most of the biggest U.S. banks. All of them reported that women and men were paid substantially the same amount, but none of the companies said how they calculated the figures and all were adjusted for factors such as seniority and job role.  JPMorgan, Citigroup JPMorgan Chase & Co., Citigroup Inc., Bank of New York Mellon Corp., Wells Fargo & Co. and Bank of America Corp. all have said this year that they paid women roughly 99 percent of what men earn. Women make up 50 percent of American Express 9s work force and only 30 percent of managers, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. The U.S. gender pay gap has been stuck at around 20 percent for the past decade, according to the National Women 9s Law Center.  cWomen are still 20 percent more likely to leave a career in finance than any other industry -- that 9s bad for business and it 9s bad for investors, said Arjuna Capital managing partner Natasha Lamb, who filed a shareholder proposal seeking the pay disclosure at American Express and eight other companies this year. Calling equal pay ca critical first step to retaining top talent, Arjuna withdrew its proposal in response to AmEx 9s pledge. In her withdrawal letter, Lamb said AmEx 9s review will include base, bonus and equity compensation, and the company will adjust pay to get to 100 percent equality. It will also disclose its methodology, according to Lamb.     While some analysts have questioned banks 9 assertions about a 1 percent pay gap, cthese companies along with a handful of tech and consumer firms, are at the leading edge" in U.S. gender pay equity, Lamb said.  cWith assurances that women will be paid fairly, we can focus more confidently on the next step: moving women into higher paying leadership positions, she said in an email.  _ 4 With assistance by Jennifer Surane_  ]
articles.title: American Express Joins Chorus Declaring Gender Pay Parity

articles.article: [ ![](https://www.washingtonpost.com/resizer/qrU7dLM41tudDcYzXeBb3N-qfGw=/480x0 /arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod- washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/DMCNO63OMQ2H7KFR7TLXBC75EY.jpg)  Students at Montpelier High School in Vermont raised a Black Lives Matter flag on Feb. 1, as part of activities to discuss racism. (Lisa Rathke/AP) Teachers and students across the country this week are diving into lessons and conversations, drawing pictures and reciting poems, singing and reading about issues that are central to the Black Lives Matter at School movement: institutional racism, black history and identity, and restorative justice. It was started by teachers, parents and administrators and is connected with 4 but not directly related to 4 the Black Lives Matter movement. It has drawn support from unions, school boards and other organizations.  cIt really shows what real grass-roots education reform can look like, said Jesse Hagopian, a high school history teacher in Seattle who helped found Black Lives Matter at School and wrote about it[ here](https://www.rethinkingschools.org/articles/how-one-elementary-school- sparked-a-citywide-movement-to-make-black-students-lives-matter) and [here](http://progressive.org/public-school- shakedown/blacklivesmatteratschool-a-national-uprising-for-racial-just/). Organizers say thousands of teachers signed up to participate in activities during this week, which is part of Black History Month. Curriculum and resources have been provided [online here](https://twitter.com/councilofdc/status/961202921303093248/photo/1?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.washingtonpost.com%2Flocal %2Fdc-politics%2Ftanks-but-no-tanks-dc-officials-pan-trumps-proposed-grand- military-parade%2F2018%2F02%2F07%2F5e09c558-0c1b- 11e8-8890-372e2047c935_story.html) and[ here.](https://www.dcareaeducators4socialjustice.org/black-lives-matter- resources) In [Prince George 9s County](http://pgcea.org/wp- content/uploads/sites/13/2018/02/BLM-Week-of-Action-2018-Final.pdf)\xa0in Maryland, one of the country 9s wealthiest black-majority counties,[\xa0hundreds of ](http://pgcea.org/wp- content/uploads/sites/13/2018/02/BLM-Week-of- Action-2018-Final.pdf)participating teachers wore black on Monday to show support for the week, and on Tuesday, their students were asked to write essays to this prompt: cWhy is Black Lives Matter relevant to them as students/community/school? The Prince George 9s County Board of Education [passed a resolution](https://www.boarddocs.com/mabe/pgcps/Board.nsf/files/AVJKN2527B44/$file/Black%20Lives%20Matter%20at%20Schools%20Week.pdf) supporting the week. In Seattle, the School Board formally endorsed the week with a resolution, saying: > Historically, when black people have fought for a more democratic society, the lives of all people have improved and, conversely, each time barriers to black people 9s potential have been erected, our whole society has suffered. This resolution makes the unequivocal declaration from the School Board that the lives of our black students matter, as well as the lives of all of our students of color. It also encourages participation district-wide in the Black Lives Matter At School Week from February 5-9. This week is being recognized by educators nationwide as an opportunity to promote racial justice and identity safety in classrooms. Several Pennsylvania school boards endorsed the week, too, including the William Penn School District board, which issued a resolution urging teachers and students to participate in activities for the week. The Milwaukee Teachers 9 Education Association endorsed it, too, encouraging members to wear Black Lives Matter shirts during the week and to teach lessons that address the cschool-to-prison pipeline, the empowerment of black women, black history and the black LGBTQ community. > Milwaukee Public Schools [BlackLivesMatteratSchool](https://twitter.com/hashtag/BlackLivesMatteratSchool?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) Week of Action Kicks Off!<https://t.co/S9gXL6MX3f>[BlackLivesMatter](https://twitter.com/hashtag/BlackLivesMatter?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) [pic.twitter.com/nlgtVWABwj](https://t.co/nlgtVWABwj) > > 4 MTEA (@MTEAunion) [February 8, 2018](https://twitter.com/MTEAunion/status/961660763965480961?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) In New York, activities include a panel discussion at the Brooklyn Museum about community schools and how they help black communities that have not had the financial resources to build equitable public schools. The organizers of Black Lives Matter at School week issued a call to education policymakers for:  4 An end to czero tolerance disciplinary policies and the implementation of restorative justice.  4 The hiring of more black teachers.  4 A mandate that K-12 schools teach black history and ethnic studies. Guidelines for teachers\xa0[were posted on the week 9s website](https://blacklivesmatteratschool.org/): > **Basic Understandings:**  * > Black Lives Matter.  * > Affirmation and understanding should go beyond one day, one week, one month. It should be happening all of the time  * > Center Black voices in your classroom.  * > Recognize that if you are a white person, you are limited in what you understand about being black.  * > Focus on empowerment.  * > Go beyond the everyday heroes.  * > Don 9t just focus on slavery. > Thursday!
